headline: Chef John's Stuffed Peppers
description: This is the best stuffed peppers recipe. Simply fill bell peppers with a mix of rice, ground beef and pork sausage for an easy yet satisfying supper.

video.description: Tender sweet peppers stuffed full of flavor.
video.name: Chef John's Stuffed Peppers

name: Chef John's Stuffed Peppers
recipeIngredient: 1 cup uncooked long grain white rice
0.25 pound hot Italian pork sausage, casing removed
1 cup finely grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese, plus more for topping
4 large green bell peppers, halved lengthwise and seeded

recipeInstructions.text: Bring rice and water to a boil in a saucepan over high heat. Reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer until the rice is tender, and the liquid has been absorbed, 20 to 25 minutes. Set the cooked rice aside.
Meanwhile, preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
Make sauce: Cook onion and olive oil over medium heat until onion begins to soften, about 5 minutes. Transfer 1/2 of the cooked onion to a large bowl and set aside.
Stir marinara sauce, beef broth, balsamic vinegar, and red pepper flakes into the skillet with cooked onion; cook and stir for 1 minute.
Pour sauce mixture into a 9x13-inch baking dish and set aside.

Combine ground beef, Italian sausage, diced tomatoes, Italian parsley, garlic, salt, black pepper, and cayenne pepper into the bowl with reserved onions; mix well. Stir in cooked rice and Parmigiano Reggiano. Stuff green bell peppers with beef and sausage mixture.

Place stuffed green bell pepper halves in the baking dish over tomato sauce; sprinkle with remaining Parmigiano-Reggiano, cover baking dish with aluminum foil, and bake in the preheated oven for 45 minutes.
Remove aluminum foil and bake until the meat is no longer pink, the green peppers are tender and the cheese is browned on top, an additional 20 to 25 minutes.

review.reviewBody: Easy and flavorful.
Its amazing but I would double the sauce. I also make it in individual dishes and freeze it after its cooked. It warms up great.

This recipe turned out wonderful. My husband loved it. This is going to be one that I will definitely make again. I did use Sauzon Tropical to season the meat mix rather than the suggested seasonings and I used beef broth to cook the rice. I had several packages of shredded Italian blend cheese, so I used that instead of the suggested cheese.

I did make some small changes to this. Used poblano peppers, also sushi rice. Used one pound of hot sausage with one pound of ground beef, instead of marinara used canned tomato sauce, and used rotel for the diced tomatoes. Froze the extra meat mix for later. My husband loved it. My picky teen loved it. It smelled amazing being made.

Tried this recipe today. Was GREAT! Really good! Nice amount of flavour and spice!! Had a little filling leftover - enough for a couple of cabbage rolls or another two halves pepper. I used OLD CHEDDAR as I didn't have the parm.

This is one of my FAVORITE Chef John recipes! The only thing I change is I use an entire pound of hot sausage along with the 1 lb of ground beef. This makes even MORE "stuffing". I use 3 LARGE peppers (red, yellow orange) -- I'm not a green pepper fan -- and de-seed and slice them in half for 6 large halves. Stuff those to the max and any stuffing left over is jammed in between the pepper halves and cooked right along side the stuffed peppers! Absolutely delicious! Chef John is the MAN! His recipes are the bomb!
Chef John is a rock star………this recipe needs no adjusting. Perfect!

They are in the oven cooking now. A note regarding quantity of the meat. Too much meat mixture for 4 peppers (and I used LARGE peppers in preparation for this dish). Could have used 5 or 6 peppers. Had one for dinner; it's delish!!!! I went very light on the addition of hot chili flakes. Used ground beef no lamb. Try the mix next time.

Really fantastic stuffed peppers! I made just a few small changes - only used 1 cup of cooked rice instead of 2 - used 1/2 cup water instead of full cup of beef broth - used 2 tbsp balsamic and 24 oz marinara sauce - Did not add extra cheese to the top Best stuffed peppers ever!

This was fantastic. I didn't have hot italian sausage, which I'm sure would have made it phenomenal, so I subbed extra ground beef and added some italian herbs, and extra red pepper flakes, and a touch of fennel. And after reading the reviews made a little extra sauce. We made a soup with the leftover stuffed pepper and I added the leftover sauce and leftover beef broth. So good.
We substituted hot Italian sausage and Rotel tomatoes into the recipe. Just the right level of spicy.
I'm planning on making these again! This is such a great recipe. The basalmic vinegar surprised me! It is needed and VERY GOOD!
This was delicious, but I browned the meat first. Second night I cut up leftover peppers and used the sauce on pasta, another great meal!

These are the BEST stuff peppers my wife or I have ever had (53 and 56 years old) Great recipe! As is!!! I like cooking it all at one time even though it takes longer much better and never dry or over done. Made this multiple times and is our go to recipe for stuffed peppers. I love Chef Johns recipes. They are spot on almost every time! Thank you Chef!!!!
This recipient is excellent! I made these per directions and used red, yellow and orange peppers. We were very pleased with the result.
Adjusted to my Texas twist with salsa and jalapenos. Delicioso!

I liked it. I used riced cauliflower in place of rice. I also added a can of drained diced tomatoes for more tomato texture. The last ten minutes of bake time I added shredded mozzarella cheese to the tops of each pepper.

My entire family loved Chef John’s recipe for stuffed peppers. I’ve made peppers in the past but none that taste this delicious. They were very moist. I used ground beef and Italian ground turkey for the meat filling. Perfect combination. I also added more seasonings like garlic powder, onion powder, basil and Tony’s Cajun seasoning.

These Stuufed Bells did not disappoint! I like other reviewers had more filling than need for the peppers being cooked. I made a few adjustments for a vegetarian meal; the recipe converted very easily and tasty to boot.

This recipe is amazing. I used ground turkey and spicy chicken sausage for a heart healthy family member. Even with these lower fat/flavor substitutions, these were unbelievably delicious. Bonus - the extra stuffing I had at the end made a wonderful turkey burger recipe.
These were delicious!! My husband and I loved them.
Excellent! Will double the sauce next time though.
Love them a lot. Peppers were done. But needed more seasoning.
Superb. I substituted ground turkey for ground beef, and I omitted the salt. Still outstanding.
I am not a cook. I have difficulty with making anything come out delicious. However, I made these peppers and OMG they were amazing! Easy to do and just perfect!

I will definitely make this again. I pretty much stuck to the instructions but i cooked the pepper halves in boiling water for 3 minutes before i stuffed them since we like our peppers more tender. They were still crisp tender after cooking in the oven. I used a spicy tomato basil sauce for the base and a can of rotel tomatoes to add more spice to to the meat mixture. The sauce and the meat mixture were very flavorful but not overly spicy. I omitted the cheese since we do not eat cheese.

I loved this recipe! The video doesn't jibe with the written instructions, so I combined elements from each. Chef John stands his peppers on end, but I found it easier to slice them in half, and bake them on their sides. The filling makes more than enough for the four peppers called for, so I'll use five or six the next time ( and there WILL be a next time!), and I used John's suggestion to add some of the marinara to the filling. Since I'm not a fan of "heat", I'll probably eliminate the red pepper flakes in the sauce, but will leave the cayenne pepper in the filling. I'm so excited to find a stuffed pepper recipe I really enjoy!

Chef John's stuffed peppers was delicious! Very easy to follow instructions and the time it took to cook the rice - 20 min. - and brown the ground meat, etc, they were ready to pop into the oven. I changed up things a bit. I cooked the meat mixture together with the cooked rice before stuffing it into the peppers. Next time, I will follow Chef John's instructions exactly because I believe, it saves time getting it in the oven!
Absolutely amazing! I wouldn’t change a thing!
The very best Stuffed Bell Peppers I've ever had! Top Notch! Not your Grandma's stuffed peppers! Woo hoo! Try it, you'll like it!!!!
Been waiting for this! Yummo! Yes you might extra filling, but just freeze it because you will want these again very soon! Don’t skip the balsamic vinegar in the sauce. Great flavors!
I have made these several times and everytime they come out amazing. This is my favorite stuffed pepper recipe ever!
I added mozerella cheese to the top of mine.

I made this exactly the way the recipe was written and it was the best stuffed pepper recipe I have ever made. I love this in the colder months when you want something a bit heartier for dinner. I also love the fact that there is a sauce with them as well.
Absolutely lovely recipe! I made it exactly as listed except no red pepper flakes as husband can’t handle. Couldn’t have asked for more and husband said best ever:) Thank you CJ !
These stuffed peppers are awesome. My whole family enjoys these delicious peppers. Thank you Chef John!

Delicious! I parboiled my peppers and cooked my ground beef mixture then stuffed my peppers. I didn’t have any sausage so I used a sprinkle of fennel seed. I also used fresh chopped tomatoes. Used an Italian blend cheese instead of the parm-regg because that’s what I had. Baked in oven for about 30 minutes. I will be using this recipe from now on!
This fun to make & tastes AMAZING!
The result was a great success. I will make this again. I must admit it is a somewhat complicated recipe to produce, but the result was well worth the effort.
I parboiled the pepper halves prior to baking. Do not pre-cook the meat. I added Trader Joes Sofrito seasoning and it really elevated the flavor. It was a hit with our guests.
I used hot sauce instead of red pepper. The rest of recipe the same. Easy and delicious.
Supper Easy, However I used instead of ground beef I used ground chicken and ground turkey

This was delicious because the combination of marinara, beef stock, and balsamic vinegar is unbelievable! Following the direction this sauce would only go under the stuffed peppers, but it's so good I mixed it right in to the filing. You should too! I also cooked all the meat in a skillet before mixing the filing so that I could shorten my oven cook time. My suggestion is to bake a total of 1 hour. The first 30 minutes, just the bell pepper cups and a half cup of water, to stream them. Then another 30 once they're stuffed.

I added just 1 cup cooked rice to the meat and served the rest with the sauce over it. Spooned some sauce over the tops before cooking. Cooking times are perfect. I've made this recipe several times and my family loves it.
I cut the peppers in half and stuffed them so the portions would be more in line with what we eat. That worked well. Flavor is awesome
These are the best stuffed peppers I have ever had! Due to the price of bell peppers, I used poblano instead, which added an extra kick. I will be making this frequently! Thanks Chef John!

I was real tempted to add some more spices but I left it alone for my first go round even though it was begging for more. A Mexican, Indian and Chinese version are coming together in my brain. Great dish

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ We loved this!! (But you definitely need more than 4 peppers!) Changes: My peppers were small to medium, and I used 7. I could only find mild Italian sausage, and I used a 14.5 oz can of diced tomatoes (but didn’t use all the liquid from the can). The cooking time seemed perfect. Actually, everything was perfect! We will definitely make these again. And I love someone else’s idea to use this recipe for cabbage rolls!! 😃
I loved this didn't change a thing!!

This was a very satisfied meal. Please with the exact recipe however I made it with different colors of peppers to give it more color to the dish . I also added jalapeños to the dish to make it extra spicy just the way I like it . For sure will make it again .

Thank you for this absolutely delicious stuffed pepper recipe. I never cared for stuffed peppers until l tried this recipe. I’ve made these several times now and they always turn out great! The last time l made them l decided to repurpose the left overs . A day or so later I chopped up the stuffed peppers l had left and put them in burrito shells with a little cheese. Rolled them up and baked them covered just long enough to heat up with a little verde sauce and cheese on top! New favorite burritos!!
My family loved it! Especially my type 1 diabetic selective eater.

I will make it. The video and the written recipe are different. The video puts the peppers in on their bases. The written recipe uses halves of peppers and puts canned tomatoes in the stuffing. I'm curious about this version because in other recipes I have found that blanching the peppers is really worth it. I hate blanching things but it makes the pepper skins tender.

My neighbor made this recipe - posting a photo of it on Facebook with comments about how good it was. Since I've been looking for a good stuffed pepper recipe for years, I made it, and now it's my go-to stuffed peppers recipe. I used only red peppers, because of their sweetness. It was surprising how large, and filling each half portion was.
We like yellow and we agree cutting in half lengthwise works best since finding any that stand up straight is challenging,laying flat looks cool.

I came across this recipe almost 2 years ago and it has become my only stuffed pepper recipe. I absolutely love this…. Especially how tender they come out without first boiling the peppers! Absolutely hands down the best
I’ve made these several times and these stuffed peppers are delicious. I cut up the leftovers, added a pasta sauce and served it over penne. Yum yum!
Superb just as written.

Hands down, this is THE absolute best stuffed peppers recipe I have ever tasted. As an extra bonus, when we ate the leftovers several days later, we were surprised that the flavor was even BETTER. I'll never look for another stuffed peppers recipe.

Best Stuffed Peppers I've ever had! I usually wing it on measuring ingredients, but decided to follow the recipe exactly. They turned-out delicious. If you like stuffed peppers you gotta try this recipe.

I'll add my 5 stars to this one. I made three changes: I used ground turkey (because $$$$); I had no beef broth & used vegetable broth; and I used brown rice. So all in all, it was pretty much the recipe as written. And it was truly delicious. The sauce is incredible. I had two beautiful big green peppers from my CSA and adjusted the recipe for 4. There are only 2 of us, so I froze 2 to have later. I think a veggie version, with corn, beans, celery, mushrooms would be very good, too.
No meat, love it! Vegetarian 😊

Made this twice. Once with ground beef and another time with ground turkey. I also used a whole pound of Italian sausage and cooked the rice in water with "Better than Bullion". There was a lot of extra stuffing because of the extra Italian sausage... I made extra peppers and also formed some into meatballs. Everyone that tried them thought they were amazing both times I made them.
Loved it!!!! Instead of parsely I used cilantro and Homemmade Sofrito 🖤🖤🖤
Loved it
I thought this turned out perfect! I did add some garlic powder and onion powder to it as well!! We have 5 teenage boys and a couple of them are picky eaters but they all loved it!!! ❤️❤️❤️
added some mushrooms

These were easy and delicious! I deconstructed it though to suit my lazy husband. I chopped the green peppers and cooked with the oil and onion, but did not put half of this mixture aside. I followed the rest of the recipe but obviously didn’t stuff the peppers, then mixed all the ingredients together and baked in a casserole dish. My husband is such a boiled potato that he refuses to use a knife and fork to cut up a green pepper, so this is perfect for him. Once I lovingly grilled a beautiful striploin steak for him and he threw a fit. Why? Because it wasn’t cut into small edible pieces. His mouth is so big that I thought the whole steak would fit in his mouth in one bite and I said so, so he banished me to the attic for a month, locking me in and shoving some Velveeta Cheese under the door occasionally. There’s an old sink up there with a rusty spigot that sputters water so I did not die of dehydration. When he let me out, I promised to try harder. Tonight after this dinner of Chef John’s Stuffed Peppers, he declared me the best wifey in the land and let me watch sports with him, ON THE COUCH!!, (not the floor by his feet where he usually lets me sit if I have been good). When I asked who the athletes were wearing the blue and white outfits, he screamed “They’re uniforms!” and sent me packing up to the old attic again. It’s actually kinda nice up here. Nice and unhusbandy. When I was still downstairs I had the foresight to make an emergency food kit and stashed it up here so this time I have lots of good food. Big bonus is I don’t have to look at his boiled potato face with his parsnip nose.

The flavor was delicious with the addition of sausage but I knew from experience the recipe called for too much rice. I cut the rice in half and still had to pack filling into 8 huge bell pepper halves to use it all. I didn't have marinara sauce to I substituted a can of stewed tomatoes. Also my sausage was very spicy so I omitted the cayenne and red pepper flakes. I will make this again with my changes. Thanks Chef John Update: I made these last night for my daughter and son and grandchildren ( and they were delicious!) and was wondering why the sauce had to be cooked first when dish bakes for over an hour. In your video you don't precook sauce so next time I'll try it by just pouring sauce ingredients into baking dish and will update. Update: Yeah, I tried this again and IMO there is no need to cook the sauce before pouring over the peppers.

I love these stuffed peppers. I take it a step further by making my own marinara with San Marzano tomatoes, and I make enough that I don't need to add the diced tomatoes (since the San Marzanos are whole peeled, I still have some small chunks). And instead of adding the beef broth, I simply add a package of Savory Choice beef broth concentrate and the balsamic right to the Marinara. For those who say they always have extra "stuffing", just mix that meat/rice mixture right in with the marinara on the bottom - bonus yumminess! Super easy recipe and wonderful flavors Chef John!
Great flavors!

It was okay. Don’t get me wrong- the peppers tasted good enough to eat, but I only gave 3 stars because of one: the time it took to prepare and cook (2 hours & some change if you’re not quick in the kitchen like myself), and the second reason for my rating: the peppers came out quite spicy. I used red, yellow, & orange bell peppers rather than green because I don’t care for green bell peppers, however I now see why this recipe calls for green ones. Green peppers would go much better with the spicy flavors in this recipe, but it still tastes great with other color peppers. I actually love spice, but these were a little much for me. I know the recipe calls for chili flakes, cayenne, & spicy Italian sausage, but it didn’t call for an amount of each that I would think would cause them to be as spicy as they came out. There’s no warning letting you know the spice level and I think there definitely should be. If you’re not a fan of spice I would suggest either not using one of the spicy ingredients or swapping the spicy Italian sausage for mild and decreasing the amount of chili flakes & cayenne the recipe calls for. Just my advice!
Good recipe and did not have to switch up ingredients. I’ve made this twice - unless your peppers are huge, you’ll have enough filling for a few more. I used the leftover stuffing for zucchini’s.
Delicious…one of our family’s favorite!
Everyone really loved this recipe! Thank you!

So confused, sorry to say. The written directions are completely different from the video - did anyone else notice that? So I did my best. 4 stars because they turned out delicious. But I had to work for it.

I've made this recipe several times. I gave it 4 stars because there's room for creativity to raise it to 5 stars. I like that the sauce is very simple. And it tastes good. I always make my own sauces from scratch . Marinara, Alfredo, etc. This simple flavor is good yet different from my usual.
Hands down the best stuffed pepper recipe yet. Highly recommend!

These were fantastic!!! I used homemade tomato sauce and brown rice. I added some mozz to the mix and the top. I’m sure the recipe is spot on the way it’s written. My son was literally yelling how good they were!!!

I followed the recipe to a T. I had a little bit extra sausage and I knew I wanted leftover filling because the Hubbs doesn’t like cooked sweet peppers. I prepared four large peppers(halved)and two porcupine meatballs the day before and then baked them the next evening. Rave reviews from my mother-in-law. ;)
I think this recipe as written has an error. The recipe says it serves 8, but only calls for 4 peppers. There's certainly enough filling to stuff 8 peppers. Suggest updating the pepper number to 8.

The flavors in this were perfect. I did make some changes based on my own thoughts and on some reviews. I poured a third of the marinara mix onto the bottom of the pan and the remaining 2/3's over the top of the recipe before going into the oven. I also baked at 350 rather than the higher temp suggested, then turned up to 370 after removing lid for the last 15 minutes. Cook time was 50 minutes or so, but I prepared 1/2 recipe and like the peppers a bit more firm. Will definitely make again, but will decrease rice amount by 25% and increase meat by 25% (give or take).
Wife loves it. Simple fun method that works as written or with whatever you have on hand.
I’ve read the reviews on countless websites for stuffed peppers. So many mention “lacks flavor” or “bland”. Not this one. Chef John hits it out of the park here, as usual.

This is a fantastic recipe! Everything I've tried that Chef John has submitted is terrific. The only thing I'm going to add next time is some fresh basil because I used a meat sauce with this recipe that leaned more toa Italian Sausage flavor & since there is Italian sausage in the stuffing it could use basil. I may just switch to a tomato basil sauce. I'm also going to bake a rosemary bread to go along with it next time & serve Asparagus roasted in a yummy lemon butter sauce on the side. Bon Appetit!
So delicious! The video and recipe are a bit different. I used the easiest part of both and it was delicious!

I even screwed up some of the steps because I was in a hurry and hadn’t read the recipe all the way through yet.. and they were STILL awesome! The sauce was bit too spicy for my elderly parents but the rest of us loved them!
This is delicious as is! My husband is a meat and potatoes man but he really likes this. I've tried several of Chef John's recipes and all have been a big hit.
This was by far the best stuffed pepper recipe I have ever made. I used ground chicken instead of beef. So good!
Have made it several times now. Delicious! A keeper!

I have another stuffed pepper recipe from this site that I typically use but thought I’d give another one a try. Mix it up. Wow!! We loved this version and this one is actually is a little easier than my normal go-to! Made exactly as written and turned out beautifully and delicious! The spicy sausage adds a nice heat. The only change I would do next time is add some mozzarella or Italian shredded cheese to the meat mix - a preference only. Maybe some red pepper flakes? Not needed but we like our stuffed peppers with a little more cheese and I like a little more heat. As always Chef John- thank you!

made this tonight. rather simple recipe. everyone liked it. i personally prefer more tomato flavor, might add some tomato paste to the sauce next time. no real mention of how to use the sauce, we just ladled some over the peppers when serving them. good recipe though, we'll make this again, along with the other variations we like.

I pretty much love ANYTHING by Chef John but THESE are especially wonderful to me. My daddy made the BEST stuffed bell peppers and when he passed unexpectedly, the recipe went with him. He never even told my mom! I’ve spent 15 years disappointed by every stuffed bell pepper I ever ate…. Until THESE! I can’t believe I’d say this but the are even better than my dad’s. (Forgive me, Daddy.??) They are now a family favorite that we make a regular menu item! (DONT CHANGE A THING!)

This is a keeper. It takes a bit of time to make- but well worth it. Even my picky eater gave it two thumbs up. He never eats green peppers and he ate it. Made it as is with ground Turkey. I used ground Turkey, because that is what I had. Can’t wait to try it with beef.

This is hands down the best stuffed peppers I have ever made. I didn’t have marinara sauce so used Classico Pasta Sauce with Italian Sausage. I meant to take a picture but it smelled so good while baking that I forgot.

First time ever making stuffed peppers and very happy. Others that I have had in the past always seemed a bit bland to me, but this recipe offers some great flavor. Will look to kick it up a notch with some additional heat next time!

It came out awesome. Bravo. I’m an ole fussy Italian cook and this met my standards and at my age referring to a cookbook help me with timing. Thanks for these wonderful recipe,couldn’t of done it this well without you Chef John
Another great recipe, my picky 17 year old even liked the bell peppers and he never eat bell peppers…
Making this again Sunday first was really good !! Just needed garlic bread ??
